title: test(es): Add an execution test system
body:
Description:

As we have a way to verify that input is behaving identically, we create a huge matrix of compile options and process the input with all of those options.

This system can be used to check for fixed issues easily.
For first, someone can add issues using a unix hidden directory, which starts with `.`. Those tests are ignored by `testing::fixture`.
Then, when something is changed, one can run `./scripts/check-issues.sh`. If a test succeeds, it means it's fixed and the starting dot (`.`) of the path to the test input file is removed.


**Related issue (if exists):**

title: perf(es/minifier): Use `Vec<u8>` as a buffer for `base54`
body:

We are only using ASCII characters so we can avoid utf8 logics by using `Vec<u8>` as a buffer and converting it into `String` at the end.

title: perf(es/minifier): Merge hashmap for scoping before checking
body:
**Description:**

Currently, we check for child scopes by doing a recursive call, like https://github.com/swc-project/swc/blob/2ad0d801a2a9d84ae2c6df2d15ff8a215f296eec/crates/swc_ecma_minifier/src/pass/mangle_names/analyzer/scope.rs#L112-L114

But this is slow because it results in an enormous amount of calls.

We can optimize this by merging information of child scopes beforehand.


This makes huge difference, so I decided to include this in v1.2.154



**Related issue (if exists):**

title: perf(es/minifier): Make mangler faster by merging hash sets into one
body: **Description:** I'm trying to reproduce benchmark results in https://github.com/privatenumber/minification-benchmarks **Related issue (if exists):** --- With `RAYON_NUM_THREADS=2` ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29931815/158005079-5cef38f5-d606-4128-af0f-77a25cb2d15f.png) --- After profiling, I improved the performance a lot. I merged two hashsets into one. - antd: 2.4s => 1.7045s - d3: 172ms => 155.72ms - echarts: 1.1s => 894.69ms - jquery: 35ms => 34.951ms - lodash: 38.5ms => 39.341ms - moment: 21ms => 19.915ms - react: 8ms => 7.7071ms - terser: 87.132ms => 85.408ms - three: 205ms => 191.21 ms - typescript: 6.1s => 4.2862 s - victory: 691ms => 517.86 ms - vue: => 47.745ms

title: build(cargo): set workspace default members
body:
<!-- Note: CI script will automatically rebase your PR so please do not rebase unless required -->

<!-- Thanks for submitting a pull request! Please provide enough information so that others can review your pull request. -->

**Description:**

Possible approaches for https://github.com/swc-project/swc/pull/3977 : 

It's non-fancy workaround. Basically, omit offending package (node / wasm) from default workspace build selection. `cargo build` skips those and we have to manually run each build scripts (`npm run build` for /node, `scripts/build.sh` for /wasm). To get the right binary those scripts are needed anyway, however I'm not sure about implications like `cargo check` _may_ miss to run over those packages. 

The other approach is having better build system to control build scripts instead of cargo. Given the scope of the work we need to achieve here, that's something I'd like to defer for now unless it shows visible gains for us.

**Related issue (if exists):**

title: feat(es/minifier): remove pure calls
body:
<!-- Note: CI script will automatically rebase your PR so please do not rebase unless required -->

<!-- Thanks for submitting a pull request! Please provide enough information so that others can review your pull request. -->

**Description:**

remove call/new/tagged tempalte with `/*#__PURE__*/` comments. However
```js
class A extends B {}
```
still cannot be removed in es5 target. It's because we use exact same ident for the `var A` and `function A`
```js
var A = function(B) {
    "use strict";
    _inherits(A, B);
    var _super = _createSuper(A);
    function A() {
        _classCallCheck(this, A);
        return _super.apply(this, arguments);
    }
    return A;
}(B);
```
However, we cannot change any of them. If we change `var A` to private_ident, all reference outside class would be broken. And if we set `function A` to private_ident, function name would unnecessarily change.

**BREAKING CHANGE:**

<!--
If this PR introduces a breaking change, it must contain a notice for it to be included in the CHANGELOG. Add description or remove entirely if not breaking.

You may need to update `MIGRATION.md` for the breaking changes.
-->

**Related issue (if exists):**

title: fix(es/transforms/compat): comment position in class and arrow
body:
<!-- Note: CI script will automatically rebase your PR so please do not rebase unless required -->

<!-- Thanks for submitting a pull request! Please provide enough information so that others can review your pull request. -->

**Description:**

code
```js
// 123
class A extends B {
}
```

before
```js
var A = // 123
(function (B) {})(B)
```

after
```js
// 123
var A = (function (B) {})(B)
```

code
```js
const a = () => /* 123 */ 1
```

before
```js
const a = function a() {
   /* 123 */ return 1
}
```

after
```js
const a = function a() {
  return /* 123 */ 1
}
```
**BREAKING CHANGE:**

<!--
If this PR introduces a breaking change, it must contain a notice for it to be included in the CHANGELOG. Add description or remove entirely if not breaking.

You may need to update `MIGRATION.md` for the breaking changes.
-->

title: fix(trace): adjust tracing span level
body:
<!-- Note: CI script will automatically rebase your PR so please do not rebase unless required -->

<!-- Thanks for submitting a pull request! Please provide enough information so that others can review your pull request. -->

**Description:**

- closes https://github.com/swc-project/swc/issues/3863.

I tried various approach to preserve compile time trace level but only enable Level::TRACE for `span` only. However, it simply not seems possible. The reason I choose trace level at the moment is I was under assumption it's the only level tracing spans will try to use and would possible to enable it selectively. Both seems incorrect - first, trace level can be used for logging any span-less event, or other places. Secondly, as said above we can't opt in to enable span's trace level.

PR changes span's level into `info`. This is not a regression or defeating back: https://tracing.rs/tracing_attributes/attr.instrument.html# If we didn't choose level intentionally it would been `info` all the time and we won't hit this problem from beginning.

> instruments a function to create and enter a tracing [span](https://docs.rs/tracing/latest/tracing/span/index.html) every time the function is called.
> Unless overriden, a span with info level will be generated.

WIth this PR, only tracing `spans` will be recorded as info. Any other traces, logs, or events can use TRACE | DEBUG level and `@swc/core` release binary will not emit those at all.


**BREAKING CHANGE:**

<!--
If this PR introduces a breaking change, it must contain a notice for it to be included in the CHANGELOG. Add description or remove entirely if not breaking.

You may need to update `MIGRATION.md` for the breaking changes.
-->

**Related issue (if exists):**

```
running 8 tests
test angular       ... bench:   7,431,479 ns/iter (+/- 198,154) = 96 MB/s
test backbone      ... bench:   1,041,447 ns/iter (+/- 27,429) = 57 MB/s
test colors        ... bench:      14,379 ns/iter (+/- 257) = 80 MB/s
test jquery        ... bench:   5,720,166 ns/iter (+/- 141,980) = 46 MB/s
test jquery_mobile ... bench:   9,074,520 ns/iter (+/- 123,993) = 49 MB/s
test mootools      ... bench:   4,396,554 ns/iter (+/- 104,997) = 36 MB/s
test underscore    ... bench:     897,749 ns/iter (+/- 17,875) = 48 MB/s
test yui           ... bench:   4,301,158 ns/iter (+/- 98,899) = 78 MB/s
```

<!-- Note: CI script will automatically rebase your PR so please do not rebase unless required -->

<!-- Thanks for submitting a pull request! Please provide enough information so that others can review your pull request. -->

**Description:**

For bigint,
`ident ++` cannot be transformed into `ident = ident + 1`

```javascript
export let foo = 1n;

foo++;
```

**BREAKING CHANGE:**

title: fix(optimization/inlining): Prevent inlining of vars used in rhs of binary expressions
body:
<!-- Note: CI script will automatically rebase your PR so please do not rebase unless required -->

<!-- Thanks for submitting a pull request! Please provide enough information so that others can review your pull request. -->

**Description:**
Fixes https://github.com/swc-project/swc/issues/3816

We were not correctly handling right hand-side of binary expressions during inlining optimization.

This PR parses rhs of binary expression with conditional scope to prevent inlining of vars used in rhs expression.

<!-- Explain the **motivation** for making this change. What existing problem does the pull request solve? -->

<!-- Thanks for submitting a pull request! Please provide enough information so that others can review your pull request. -->

**Description:**

Some fun facts:

```javascript
ident = expr;
```
the LHS is parsed as `PatOrExpr::Pat`

```javascript
ident += expr;
```

the LHS is parsed as `PatOrExpr::Expr`

title: perf(es/ast): Implement `Clone` without inline for some enums
body:
Otherwise each crate which does a clone gets its own copy of the
implementation. This has been done for enums which were identified
as causing bloat in the output binary. This reduces the binary size
and shouldn't negatively affect performance because these were too
large to be inlined anyway.

```
   text	   data	    bss	    dec	    hex	filename
-21101321	 520952	   2560	21624833	149f801	target/release/swc
+20233529	 520984	   2560	20757073	13cba51	target/release/swc
```

title: fix(lazy/export): Fix lazy + 'export { foo } from "bar"'
body:
# Description

When using lazy dependency loading, along with `export { foo } from "bar"`, the generated code for the export currently uses a identifier property, not a function call (`_bar.foo`, instead of `_bar().foo`).

The first commit in this PR shows the problem.
The second commit fixes it.

This changes things slightly where previously `export { foo } from "bar"` was denied lazy-loading for `"bar"`. Was this for performance reasons? If it was only for performance, and if it's something we'd like to preserve, I'll introduce the necessary commit.

# Discussion

The original design of CommonJS + Lazy was different than the direction in which we're currently taking it, and I want to make sure that everyone understands, and that we're all aligned on the new design.

Originally, identifiers were denied lazy-loading on-the-fly, which led to many bugs, mostly due to the order of operations. It has since changed to use a preliminary pass using `LazyIdentifierVisitor`. The goal was to change the failure mode of `Lazy`. Before, it was able to produce faulty code. Now, the failure mode *should* be valid but unoptimized code (not always the case yet, as shown in this PR).

The way I see it, if we run `CommonJS` without `LazyIdentifierVisitor`, it should still produce valid code. `LazyIdentifierVisitor` should only be thought of as a performance optimization.

Therefore, `CommonJS` should not be making decisions as to what can and cannot be lazy loaded.
